titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Allan Gurganus Papers, 1961-2019 RL.11748
titlestmt.author: Leah M. Kerr and Bethany Lynch

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-01-04 14:15:34 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Allan Gurganus (1947- ), a gay, white, Southern writer, was born in Rocky Mount, North Carolina. Gurganus trained as a painter, served in the United States Navy during the Vietnam War, then studied at Sarah Lawrence College and the Iowa Writers' Workshop. He later taught writing at Sarah Lawrence College; the Iowa Writers' Workshop; Stanford University; and Duke University. The collection includes the following series: (1) Writings; (2) Correspondence; (3) Personal Papers; (4) Artwork; and (5) Others' Works.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arrangement follows creator's chronological dates where available. Archivist arranged where dates are not available.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Allan Gurganus (1947- ), a gay, white, Southern writer, was born in Rocky Mount, North Carolina. He trained as a painter at the University of Pennsylvania, and the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. As punishment for his draft evasion during the Vietnam War, he served as a message decoder in the United States Navy for three years. It was during his time on the USS Yorktown that he began to write. After his military service, he graduated from Sarah Lawrence College where he had studied with Grace Paley. In the Iowa Writers' Workshop at the University of Iowa, Gurganus studied with John Irving, Stanley Elkin, and John Cheever. It was Cheever who sold one of Gurganus's short stories to The New Yorker without his knowledge. "Minor Heroism" became the first story The New Yorker ever published about a homosexual character. Gurganus later taught writing at Sarah Lawrence College; the Iowa Writers' Workshop; Stanford University; and Duke University.

Extensive personal and professional correspondence between Gurganus and his family, friends, and other artists provides insight into how being gay and living in the south shaped his writing. These letters concern both personal and literary matters. Frequently the correspondents commented on each other's recent publications and work, or on projects in progress.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: In accordance with the Family Education Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 as amended, Duke University permits students to inspect their education records and limits the disclosure of personally identifiable information from education records. userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Allan Gurganus Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2012-2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Allan Gurganus Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Leah Kerr and Bethany Lynch, October 2019.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The (1) Writings Series is divided into the Books, Novellas and Articles subseries, Uncollected Works subseries, and Addresses and Speeches subseries. Gurganus's writings, collected here as manuscripts, typescripts, and proofs with notes, documenting his development of well-known and critically-acclaimed works. His collected works include White People; The Practical Heart; Plays Well with Others; and, Local Souls. Gurganus's other books and individual stories, essays, and drawings or illustrations related to the titles are included in this Series.

The (2) Correspondence Series is divided into the Chronological Correspondence subseries which consists of letters to and from Gurganus, publishers, and friends, and the Correspondence, Alphabetical by Name subseries is comprised of correspondence between Gurganus and other writers, artists, literary figures, and close friends.

The (3) Personal Papers Series contains Gurganus's family correspondence, documents, many of the books, letters, art and photographs kept in his home. Financial and legal records as well as documentation of his writing career through contracts and royalty statements are also included in this series. The (4) Artwork Series is comprised of doodles, drawings, paintings, and sketches. Series (5) Others' Works, includes books, articles, and typescripts written by friends, students, and others.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Allan Gurganus papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access restricted: Acc. 2020-0100 requires additional arrangement, description, and/or screening. Contact Research Services for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Series includes writings by Gurganus, and are arranged into the subseries Books, Novellas and Articles; and Addresses and Speeches. The Books subseries is composed chiefly of manuscripts, drafts, typescripts, and proofs of Gurganus's novels, novellas, essays, and articles with the author's notations and revisions, and provides a thorough representation of the development of each. The Uncollected Works subseries contains drafts, copies, proofs, and published works not included in Gurganus's books and novellas. Transcripts of his speeches appear in the Addresses and Speeches subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes the notes, manuscripts, drafts, revisions; correspondence; galleys; proofs; publicity; and reviews related titles of Gurganus's works. Gurganus's early work includes actual 'cut and paste' edits on typewriter drafts before his use of a computer with that same digital ability. They are arranged chronologically where dates are available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence Series is divided into the Chronological Correspondence subseries and the Correspondence, Alphabetical by Name subseries. The Chronological Correspondence subseries consists of letters to and from Gurganus. Correspondents include family, friends, artists, and admirers of his work. These letters concern both personal and literary matters. Frequently the correspondents commented on each other's recent publications and work, or on projects in progress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence between Gurganus and his family, friends, associates, students, and business contacts, and is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence between Gurganus and other artists, his family, and friends, and is arranged by last name of the correspondent, or company name. Where known, the occupation of the correspondent is included. Many Correspondence folders contain a limited number of items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from Allan Gurganus to named and unnamed correspondents. Much of this correspondence was written by Gurganus and faxed to recipients. Due to Gurganus's familiarity with his correspondents, many documents do not contain names, or are addressed affectionately to Dear One, Dearest, or Dear Heart.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Series includes family correspondence; early drawings; books; photographs; and audiovisual materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes World War II letters between Allan's parents, Ethel and Marvin Gurganus; letters from Allan to his parents written while in college; in the Navy; and later living in New York city and is arranged chronologically. Also included is correspondence between other Gurganus family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes invitations; playbills; and programs from events attended by, and of interest to Gurganus. Events include a Christmas Musical Festival; a North Carolina artists' exhibition; an Ambassador Book award; a Bessie Schonberg Tribute; a hot dog gay dance; and an Iowa Writers' Workshop paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes oversized clippings and copies of newspaper articles, including: Punch & Judy show banned as sadism; RMSHS theater productions; Vivian Smith McMillan; Gurganus Dansforth finalist; Manly Wade Wellman; Karl Wagner; A Vanishing South?; Jesse Helms articles; Joanne Meschery; Where the beat meet the elite; From Hamburger Hill to Bull Run; Teletubbies say eh-oh; Vollis Simpson; Alan Shapiro; Doug Marlette; nude images; a third grade class article; and articles regarding Gurganus.

scopecontent.p: This subseries reflects Gurganus's ongoing friendships. Memorials and obituaries are also included as Gurganus has lost friends to AIDS, or the natural aging process. Also included are articles and speeches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Series includes Gurganus's doodles, drawings, paintings, and sketches, and are arranged by materials and approximate date of creation. Instances included may be related to Gurganus titles. The early work dates from first grade, then progresses through grade school and senior high school. Sketchbooks and loose drawings reflect Gurganus's use of pencil; pen and ink; watercolors; and collage through 2018. Many of the works are undated.

accessrestrict.p: Access restricted: Acc. 2020-0100 requires additional arrangement, description, and/or screening. Contact Research Services for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The following description of the contents will need to be verified when the collection is processed: includes a scrapbook with photographs and clippings related to Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All, the 1974 issue of the New Yorker in which the story "Minor Heroism" was published (the first story that featured a gay character in the magazine), and approximately 15 letters to Gurganus from John Cheever from the 1970s.
